seriesStmt.title: Encyclopaedia Britannica: A machine-readable text transcription

availability.p: National Library of Scotland License: CC BY 4.0

listBibl.head: Alternate image sources for this edition:
listBibl.bibl: Hathi Trust, from print source at the University of Wisconsin: vol. 9, pp. 29, 31, 32, 36, 37, 39, 41, 48, 50-55, 57, 59, 62, 63, 66, 67, 69-71, 76, 88; vol. 19 (all).
Hathi Trust, from print souce at the University of Chicago: vol. 10, pp. 7-10; vols. 20, 21 (all).

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: ETTMULLER, Michel, an eminent physician, was born at Leipsic, on the 26th of May 1644. After having studied the learned languages, the mathematics, and philosophy, first in his native town, and afterwards at Wittenberg, he returned to Leipsic, and, having devoted himself wholly to medicine, obtained the degree of bachelor in 1663, and a license or diploma in 1666. But being desirous to extend his acquirements, which were already considerable, he resolved, before taking his last degrees, to visit the countries most celebrated for the cultivation of the sciences; and with this view he commenced an interesting-course of travels in Italy, sojourning for some time in the more remarkable cities of that fine country, as Naples, Rome, Florence, Bologna, Venice, Padua, Pisa, Pavia, Milan, and Turin. He then crossed the Alps and proceeded to Paris, where he remained seven months; after which he passed over into England, and thence repaired to Holland. His intention was to employ an entire winter in attending the prelections of learned professors in the university of Leyden; but his design in this respect was thwarted by his sudden recall to Lcipsic, where, on the 20th of August 1668, two days after his arrival, he received the degree of doctor, a distinction which proved the forerunner of new dignities. The Academy of the Curious in Nature admitted the young doctor one of its members in 1670, and the Faculty of Medicine in 1676. About the same time the university of Leipsic confided to him the chair of botany, and appointed him extraordinary professor of surgery; offices the duties of which he discharged with distinction. But he did not long enjoy his preferment; for, on the 9th of March 1683, he was suddenly cut off, in consequence of a hectic fever, occasioned, as some say, by a chemical experiment. Although Ettmuller only wrote short dissertations and mere opuscula, he nevertheless enjoyed an immense reputation. His feeblest productions were reprinted, translated, and commented on; nor were his lectures, collected by numerous auditors, sometimes with much inaccuracy, less favourably received by the public. He had the art of interesting and fixing the attention by a ready elocution, and by arguments much more specious than solid. Of this any one may satisfy himself by the perusal of his works, of which the following is a list: 1. DeSingularibus, a thesis defended by Ettmuller in 1663; 2. Medicina HippocratisChimica, Leipsic, 1670, in 4to; 3. Vis Opiidiaphoretica, Leipsic, 1679, in 4to; 4. ChimiαRationalisac Experimentαliscuriosa, Leyden, 1684, in 4to; 5. Medieris Theoriaet Praxi generaliinstructus, Francfort and Leipsic, 1685, in 4to; 6. Opera Omnia theoretica acpractica, Lyons, 1685, in 4to; 7. Opera Omnia;nempe InstitutionesMedicinoe cumNotis,etc. Francfort, 1688, in fol.; 8. OperaMedicatheoretico-practicα, Francfort, 1676, 2 vols, fol.; 9. OperumOmniumMedico-plnysicorumeditio novissima, Lyons, 1690, 2 vols. fol.; 10. Opera Omnia in Compendiumredacta, London, 1701, and Amsterdam, 1702, in 8vo. But of all the editions, the best is that which the son of the author published under the title of OperaMedicatheoretico-practica perfiliumMichaelem Ernestum, etc. Francfort, 1708, in 3 vols. fol. There is no complete translation of the ,works of Ettmuller, but there are numerous German, English, and French translations of the different treatises.
Michel Ernest Ettmuller, son of the preceding, born at Leipsic in 1673, was also a physician of some eminence.

Besides collecting and editing the works of ms father, which formed the principal labour of his life, he wrote a number of theses and memoirs, which are not destitute of merit, and died on the 25th September 1732. (a.)
